column1: Royal Oak is a city in Oakland County in the U.S. state of Michigan. As of the 2010 census
column2: the city had a population of 57
column3: 236.The city is located along the Woodward Corridor
column4: and Interstate 75 and Interstate 696 also pass through Royal Oak. As a northern suburb of Metro Detroit
column5: the city is about 3 miles (4.8 km) north of the city of Detroit. Portions of the Detroit Zoo are within Royal Oak

column1: Early Europeans in this area near Fort Detroit in the 18th century were mostly French Canadians; some traded with the Sauk
column2: Huron
column3: and other Native Americans in the area. After defeating France in the Seven Years' War
column4: Great Britain took control of their territory east of the Mississippi River
column5: including Fort Detroit and environs. After the American Revolutionary War
column6: Britain promoted development of what was then called Upper Canada and Province of Quebec
column7: across the Detroit and St. Clair rivers to the south and east.

column1: Royal Oak was not incorporated as a village until 1891
column2: and as a city in 1921. It was named in 1819
column3: during one of the surveying expeditions led by Territorial Governor Lewis Cass. A large oak tree at this small settlement reminded Cass of the story of the Royal Oak
column4: where King Charles II of England was said to have hid to escape capture by the Roundheads after the Battle of Worcester. Cass named the settlement after that
column5: several years after the United States had fought Great Britain across the northern border in the War of 1812.

column1: Royal Oak developed as a suburb of Detroit in the early 20th century
column2: following Detroit's booming growth as a result of industrialization and its auto industry.

column1: Royal Oak has a Council–manager government. It is governed by a city commission consisting of a mayor and six commission members. The city commission appoints a city manager
column2: who manages the day-to-day operations of the city.

column1: Royal Oak has a below-average crime rate
column2: similar to that of nearby upper middle-class communities
column3: such as Berkley and Madison Heights. Larceny-theft was the most common crime
column4: making up 66.7% of all crimes in the city. Five known murders have been committed since 2000
column5: one in 2004

column1: Royal Oak's police department has 79 sworn officers and 25 civilian personnel. The department employs community policing techniques.

Royal Oak has a full-time fire department that operates three stations strategically located around the city to minimize response time to incidents. The ROFD staffs three engines and two ALS ambulances daily and is a member of the OAKWAY mutual aid consortium.
Royal Oak developed initially as a suburb after Detroit boomed as a major industrial city. People began to move to the suburbs for newer housing
column2: especially after World War II. It had a compact
column4: which runs along Main Street and Washington Avenue downtown. During the 2000s
column5: this area was redeveloped with numerous new businesses
column6: and is now considered a trendy
column11: and entertainment. A number of mixed-use high-rise developments have been constructed — mostly condo "lofts" with retail and office space on the lower levels.

column1: The city is served by Royal Oak Neighborhood Schools. There is also a private high school
column2: Shrine Catholic. A branch of Oakland Community College is located in the city.

column1: A portion of land in the city is zoned to Berkley Public Schools.
In recent years Royal Oak has begun to consolidate its public schools in response to a decline in enrollment levels compared to the baby boom era. In 2006
column2: the city's two public high schools
column3: George A. Dondero High School and Clarence M. Kimball High School
column4: were combined into a new Royal Oak High School. Beginning in 2007
column5: the city's two middle schools were combined into one school
column6: Royal Oak Middle School. The number of elementary schools was reduced to six. Some parents protested the planned closure and demolition of Longfellow and Whittier elementary schools. They were seeking to have them considered for historic district recognition by way of signed petition. Despite their efforts
column7: both schools and a number of other former elementary schools were demolished in the fall of 2007.

column1: The Royal Oak school system gained brief notoriety for an incident following the Trump election. Some middle schoolers chanted "build that wall". A student video of the incident was widely shared on Facebook
column2: attracting more than 4 million views within 24 hours. A week later a noose was found in the 8th grade boys bathroom at the middle school. The student who had placed the noose in the bathroom was removed from the school shortly afterward.St. Dennis School of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit was formerly in Royal Oak. It closed in 2011.

column1: I-75 runs north–south along the city's east side.
I-696 runs east–west along the city's south side.
M-1 (formerly designated US 10 and also known as Woodward Avenue) runs generally southeast–northwest along the city's west side.
Five numbered east–west mile roads run through Royal Oak.
Amtrak provides service to Royal Oak
column2: operating its Wolverine three times daily in both directions between Pontiac and Chicago via Detroit.

column1: Class one freight rail service is provided by Canadian National Railway (CN).
Suburban Mobility Authority for Regional Transportation (SMART) operates local and regional bus transit.

column1: The Saginaw Trail was a footpath established by the Sauk tribe between Detroit and Saginaw. In Royal Oak present-day Main Street and Crooks Road were developed along the historic path.
Downtown Royal Oak features a wide assortment of nightlife venues
column2: including the Royal Oak Music Theatre and the Landmark Main Art Theatre. Mark Ridley's Comedy Castle
column4: was an early venue for performers such as Tim Allen and Dave Coulier. Allen's connections to Royal Oak would later in his career be alluded to in the sitcom Home Improvement as the protagonist's (played by Allen) place of residence.

column1: Royal Oak encompasses a major span of the Woodward Dream Cruise. The city sponsors ancillary events around the Cruise. It is the site of the Detroit Zoo
